caption: Saint-Leu-Saint-Gilles de Paris is a Roman Catholic parish church in the 1st arrondissement of Paris. It has housed the relics of Empress Saint Helena, mother of Emperor Constantine, for 200 years. Helena was an important person and there are still many visitors to the church precisely because of her. In 1915, the French Ministry of Culture classified it as a monument of historical value.

An amazing church open to visit and or worship most days.  It was the the church of the royals and rich centuries ago.  The holy water fountain was donated by Victor Hugo. The massive arches, carved stone pillars and spirit filled painting filled me with awe.  It is currently an active Catholic church and you can fill the spirit of worship and God. Multilingual information about the church's history and art are available.

This is a Roman Catholic parish church on Rue Saint Denis in the 1st District of Paris. It is not far north of Pompidou and can be conveniently viewed when sightseeing in the area.  Originally constructed in the 13th-century, numerous enlargements and modifications took place up until 1780, providing the bulk of the present church you see today. Recent church history is also much associated with the relics of Saint Helena, mother of early 4th-century ruler Emperor Constantine, which were transferred to the church in the late 19th century.  Due to the narrow street in front of the church, it is a bit challenging to appreciate the facade and immediate exterior of Eglise Saint-Leu-Saint-Gilles. However, you can enjoy a simple Gothic facade with side turrets on both sides of the entrance.  We further found the interior to be quite dark throughout. You can walk through the nave, viewing a fine alter with surrounding decoratively carved columns and a nicely carved pulpit. However, it was rather difficult taking pictures due to poor light conditions on the day.  There are nice stained-glass windows to see. However, quite a few within the upper level of the church were missing, at present being replaced with temporary clear glass panes. Would be nice to see the interior with replacements window panes at some point in the future.  In the end, we liked Eglise Saint-Leu-Saint-Gilles but found it more difficult to enjoy given the dark conditions on the day we visited. Will have to give her another visit in the future so that we can better view and appreciate the church.

This large quiet church, though not as old as many in Paris, still contains many treasures. Its history is simply explained in the free multilingual printed leaflets near the door. Of particular interest to musicians is the great pipe organ whose mechanism was damaged in 1974, thus rendering it unplayable, but which contains 13 ranks of pipes dating from before the French Revolution.
Beautiful church, relatively small but nice architecture. A great organ located and can be seen in the photo.
Beautiful old church, gorgeous architecture and a wonderful experience.
Traditional Roman style church in the style of the region. I think it's usually closed though I could be wrong.
A beautiful experience...
Everyone should see it ... it is a little heaven

Gothic church, dating from the 13th century, located on Rue de Saint-Denis in the city of Paris. The relics of Saint Helena are venerated there. It is currently the Chapter Church of the Knights of the Order of the Holy Sepulcher of Jerusalem.

This temple is worth a visit, because here are the relics of the Holy Equal-to-the-Apostles Queen Helen, revered by both Orthodox and Catholics. Pleasant staff who always guide you into the crypt of St. Helena. Once a month there is an Orthodox Divine Liturgy. On Fridays at 16.00 an akathist is sung in honor of the saint.

The Saint-Leu-Saint-Gilles church is located in the heart of the first arrondissement on the lively rue Saint-Denis. An imposing Gothic-style church which has many interesting stained glass windows and a remarkable organ. Classified as a historic monument, it is worth a little detour when exploring the neighborhood.

I had passed by this church several times, but this was the first time I went inside. A church that is not very large. A middle-aged man was sitting at the entrance of the church when the priest brought out a chair and asked him if he would like to sit down. At that time, I passed. He has a very kind smile and welcomes people in. A church with such a kind-hearted priest. So I thought I'd take a photo from the back and post it. It's almost attached to the building next door, but that may also be part of the church.

Beautiful church that is little noticed on rue Saint Denis, because there is little setback, no square. The stained glass windows are bright and the atmosphere is serene compared to the tumult of the neighborhood. To visit

Remains of Saint Helena. It is a beautiful church, and if you want to go down to the crypt to see the remains of the body of Saint Helena (the mother of Emperor Constantine and who found the Cross where Jesus Christ was crucified) you must ask for the key in the Sacristy. Place venerated on Fridays by the Orthodox community.
Free access church. The altar and the organ located in the choir stand out.
I love places of worship, especially Catholic ones. For me a moment of contemplation is necessary.
A very beautiful Catholic church. A beautiful monument to Gothic art.
The church of Saint-Leu-Saint-Gilles houses the relics of Empress Saint Helena, mother of Constantine. We have only seen it externally.
A church that hides little wonders
A magnificent welcome. A bright and trumpeting church that deserves to be discovered: history, works of art, organ. Ask the town hall for it to be restored.
Amazing story of this church now merged into current businesses

Magnificent church seen from the outside. The interior is no less interesting, it shines both for its simplicity and the intensity of its decorations. Each chapel and painting has an explanatory framework, which makes it accessible to those who discover it, like me, and to as many people as possible.
Magnificent little church, partly 13th century. Remarkable stained glass windows. Very beautiful organs. Very good concert venue for its rich acoustics, for having sung there and listening to sing...
Very beautiful church on rue Saint Denis in the Halles district of Paris. Don't be fooled by its small entrance, it is relatively large and very well decorated.

Beautiful church, testimony of a true Christian spirit in the middle of a neighborhood that is not the most advisable at sunset. Sober and elegant fa√ßade with its two slate towers that give it a characteristic seal. The simple and elegant interior highlights the presbytery with its ogival arches and its stone sculptures of the apostles presided over by a crucified man. The stained glass windows stand out, giving color to a somewhat dark interior. Interesting.

In the famous rue Saint Denis, this church, whose origins date back to the beginning of the 13th century and which has undergone numerous alterations, stands out with its two characteristic exterior turrets. It is Gothic in style. His choir is really beautiful I think... Unfortunately, when I visited it, I was unable to access the crypt which contains the reliquary of Saint Helena. Access denied. I'll try again next time!

Magnificent with a photo memorial of all the homeless people who have disappeared. A crypt where we discover a very beautiful reliquary of Saint Helena and a very ancient Christ figure and lots of other things to discover. A souvenir for Abb√© Pierre to absolutely visit.

Paris has many churches that can be visited on a second or third visit to Paris. As in Italy or Spain, they are not usually well lit and it is a shame to find paintings by great artists that go unnoticed.  In some churches there are classical music programs, organ concerts, and even contemporary art exhibitions.
